nodes.text: A three-level probabilistic program-level model (TRIDENT) can predict overall and per-instruction SDC probabilities without performing fault injection, with accuracy comparable to fault injection and with much higher speed and scalability
Soft transient hardware faults cause silent data corruptions (SDCs) and full hardware redundancy is expensive, motivating selective software-based protection guided by vulnerability estimation

Assumes faults occur in processor computational elements (pipeline registers and functional units), memory/caches and control logic are ECC or otherwise protected, and program does not jump to illegal addresses; SDC probability is conditioned on activated faults

TRIDENT architecture: three sub-models that compose (1) static-instruction sub-model fs for propagation within a static data-dependent instruction sequence, (2) control-flow sub-model fc to map corrupted branches to probabilities of corrupted stores, and (3) memory sub-model fm to trace corrupted stores to program output over memory dependencies

Workflow and inputs: TRIDENT requires LLVM IR program, one program input for profiling, and user-specified program output instructions; it runs a profiling phase to collect dynamic counts and an inferencing phase applying fs, fc, fm to compute per-instruction and overall SDC probabilities

fs computes per-instruction propagation/masking/crash probabilities by aggregating instruction-level tuples (propagate, mask, crash) derived from instruction semantics and profiled operands, avoiding expensive dynamic dependency graphs

fc classifies branch comparisons into non-loop-terminating (NLT) and loop-terminating (LT) and computes probabilities that branch corruption leads to stores being corrupted using branch and path execution probabilities; fm builds pruned memory dependence graphs (collapsing symmetric loop iterations) to compute propagation from corrupted stores to program output
TRIDENT is implemented as an LLVM compiler module and requires no fault injection to predict SDC probabilities for programs and individual instructions

Evaluation setup: implemented in LLVM, compared against LLFI fault injection on 11 benchmarks across varied domains, sampled 3,000 dynamic instructions for overall SDC experiments and used statistical FI as ground truth

Primary experimental results: TRIDENT predicted average overall SDC probability 14.83% versus FI measured 13.59% across 11 programs (mean absolute error 4.75%); paired t-test p-value 0.764 indicates no statistically significant difference at 95% confidence

Instruction-level accuracy: for per-instruction SDC probabilities TRIDENT predictions were statistically indistinguishable from FI in 8 of 11 benchmarks at 95% confidence (paired t-tests), outperforming two simpler models that omit fc and/or fm

Scalability result: TRIDENT incurs a fixed profiling cost (~15 minutes) then per-instruction incremental cost is small; TRIDENT was 2.37x faster than FI at 1,000 samples, 6.7x at 3,000 samples and 15.13x at 7,000 samples for overall SDC estimation and scales sub-linearly when increasing sampled instructions

Use case - selective instruction duplication: using TRIDENT-derived per-instruction SDC probabilities to solve a knapsack-style selection, duplication under 11.78% and 23.31% overheads reduced average SDC probability by 64% and 90% respectively, outperforming or matching simpler models

Limitations and sources of inaccuracy: TRIDENT simplifies masking by assuming only comparisons, logic ops and casts mask errors, does not handle bulk memory intrinsics (memcpy/memmove), conservatively assumes stores dominated by corrupted branches are corrupted, and has difficulty analyzing arbitrary corrupted store addresses; these produce errors particularly in Sad, Lulesh, Pathfinder

Comparison to prior analytic methods: PVF and ePVF overestimate SDCs because they ignore control-flow divergence and memory propagation; on the same benchmarks ePVF mean absolute error was 36.78% and PVF 75.19% versus TRIDENT 4.75%

Conclusion: TRIDENT demonstrates that a composed three-level probabilistic model can effectively and efficiently predict SDC probabilities without fault injection and can guide selective protection, with future work to consider multiple inputs and other platforms like GPUs
